title: HTML Structure and Semantics
description: Create a document skeleton: <!doctype html>, <html>, <head>, and <body>.
Use semantic elements: <header>, <nav>, <main>, <section>, <article>, and <footer> to describe page regions.
Choose headings in order (h1 → h2 → h3) to reflect hierarchy and improve screen-reader navigation.

Group related content with lists (
    ,
      ) and use

      for paragraphs.
Add landmarks and skip links (e.g., Skip to main) to help keyboard users.
practice: Build a semantic homepage with header, nav, main, and footer.

title: Accessible HTML Forms
description: Wrap each input with a <label> or use for/id so labels are programmatically associated.
Mark required fields clearly (aria-required or required attribute) and provide helper text using <small> or aria-describedby.
Group related controls with <fieldset> and <legend> (e.g., radio groups).
Validate input on the client (type, pattern, required) and show clear inline error messages.
Ensure keyboard and screen-reader access: focus order, logical tabbing, and descriptive button text.
practice: Create a contact form with required fields and descriptive labels.

title: CSS Selectors and Specificity
description: Target elements with type selectors (e.g., p), class selectors (.card), and ID selectors (#main).
Combine selectors with descendants, child (>) and sibling (+, ~) combinators for precision.
Use attribute selectors (input[type="text"]) for specific control styling.
Understand specificity: inline > ID > class > type — avoid overusing IDs for styling.
Keep rules modular: prefer classes and small, reusable selectors to minimize conflicts.
practice: Style a card list using class selectors and avoid overrides.

title: Layout with Flexbox
description: Make a container a flex context: .container { display: flex; }.
Use justify-content to control horizontal distribution (flex-start, center, space-between).
Use align-items to control vertical alignment (stretch, center, baseline).
Allow wrapping when needed: flex-wrap: wrap; and control item widths with flex-basis or flex properties.
Use gap to create consistent spacing between flex items instead of margins.
practice: Build a responsive nav and feature grid with Flexbox.

title: Responsive CSS Grid
description: Define a grid container: .grid { display: grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr); }.
Use grid-template-areas or named lines for semantic placement of regions.
Use repeat(), minmax(), and auto-fit/auto-fill for responsive column behavior.
Place items with grid-column and grid-row, or by assigning areas to children.
Combine media queries with grid changes to collapse columns on smaller screens.
practice: Create a 3-column layout that collapses to 1 column on mobile.

title: Web Typography and Readability
description: Define a readable base font-size and line-height: body { font-size: 16px; line-height: 1.5; }.
Choose font stacks with fallbacks and prefer system fonts for performance.
Control line length (measure) by constraining container width for readability (50–75 characters).
Use relative units (rem, em) for scalable typography and responsive adjustments.
Ensure sufficient color contrast between text and background for accessibility.
practice: Style headings and body text for a blog page.

title: JavaScript Basics
description: Declare variables using let and const and pick the correct one for mutability.
Work with data types (string, number, boolean, object, array) and convert types when needed.
Control flow with conditionals (if/else, switch) and loops (for, while, forEach).
Write small, single-purpose functions that accept inputs and return outputs.
Test behavior in the console and use console.log to inspect values during development.
practice: Write a function that formats a user’s name for display.

title: DOM Manipulation and Events
description: Select elements: document.querySelector and document.querySelectorAll for single/multiple nodes.
Change content and attributes with textContent, innerHTML, setAttribute, and classList methods.
Attach event listeners using element.addEventListener('click', handler) and remove when not needed.
Prevent default behavior when necessary and use event delegation for many similar elements.
Keep UI updates separate from data logic and minimize DOM writes for performance.
practice: Build a toggle menu and update content on button clicks.

title: Fetch API and JSON
description: Use fetch() with async/await to request resources: const res = await fetch(url).
Check the response: if (!res.ok) throw an error to handle HTTP failures.
Parse JSON: const data = await res.json() and validate the shape before use.
Wrap calls in try/catch and show user-friendly error messages when requests fail.
Avoid blocking the UI: show loading indicators and handle slow networks gracefully.
practice: Load a local JSON file and render items into cards.

title: LocalStorage for State
description: Save structured data using JSON: localStorage.setItem('key', JSON.stringify(value)).
Restore state at load: const value = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('key') || '[]').
Keep stored payloads small and only persist what’s necessary (IDs, settings, not large blobs).
Update storage on user actions and ensure changes are reflected in the UI immediately.
Consider expirations or versioning for stored data to handle schema changes.
practice: Save and restore a favorites list across reloads.

title: ES Modules and Organization
description: Break code into focused modules (api, dom, storage, modal) each with a single responsibility.
Export only what’s needed: export function or export default for the main entry.
Import named exports with matching names and default exports with any name you choose.
Prefer pure functions and avoid shared mutable state between modules when possible.
Use a module-aware server (or type="module" script) and test imports in the browser.
practice: Refactor monolithic script into modules: api, dom, modal.

title: Accessibility Essentials
description: Provide clear semantic structure and programmatic labels for controls (labels, aria-labels).
Manage focus order and trap focus inside modals; return focus to the trigger on close.
Ensure keyboard accessibility for all interactive elements and visible focus styles.
Use ARIA only when native HTML cannot express the semantics needed; prefer native elements.
Test with a screen reader and keyboard-only navigation to catch real-world issues.
practice: Build a modal with focus management and Escape to close.

title: Performance Basics
description: Measure first: use DevTools to identify large assets and slow network requests.
Optimize images (use webp, responsive sizes, and set width/height attributes).
Defer noncritical scripts and use async/defer for JavaScript to avoid blocking rendering.
Minimize CSS and avoid large render-blocking stylesheets; prefer critical CSS for above-the-fold.
Cache resources and use long cache lifetimes for static assets where possible.
practice: Keep a homepage under 500 kB and measure in DevTools.

title: SEO and Social Metadata
description: Write a clear, unique <title> and <meta name="description"> for each page.
Include Open Graph metadata (og:title, og:description, og:image) for rich sharing previews.
Use semantic headings and meaningful URLs (slugged, human-readable).
Provide alt text for images and structured data where applicable (JSON-LD).
Keep content focused and accessible—search engines favor usability and clarity.
practice: Add distinct meta descriptions and OG tags for each page.

title: Putting It Together
description: Plan the structure: decide which pages, modules, and components you need.
Build HTML skeletons and wire up CSS for layout and basic styles.
Add JavaScript modules to fetch data, render UI, and manage interactions.
Test responsiveness, accessibility, and performance; iterate based on results.
Deploy to a static host (GitHub Pages, Netlify) and verify production behavior.
practice: Create a mini site with dynamic content and a form action page.
